options.content:
# Example Router Dashboard

This is a sample [Apollo Router](https://router.apollo.dev) dashboard for Grafana that includes necessary metrics for the monitoring of a sucessful supergraph.

This is not fully complete, and each section should be vetted to ensure it meets your needs for your specific requirements. We've also added sections that can be removed as needed if the feature or data is not applicable, as well as sections where dpeloyment-specific visualizations should be added.

# Helpful Links

For users of the dashboard, consider adding relevant links to your infrastructure; consider adding links to: 

* Your Apollo Studio instance for this graph (or all agraphs if desired)
* Links to logging tools, ideally filtered for router-only logs
* Links to runbooks for issues
* Information about your supergraph

If desiring metrics by operation name, consider the amount of attribute cardinality this could include, as it would be N number of labels per operation name.

This is further compounded when adding other attributes, such as HTTP status codes or if there are errors. 

The cardinality could introduce billing concerns in some APM tools (such as Datadog or New Relic) where metric cardinality is an important facet of pricing.

For request rates by operations: `sum by(graphql_operation_name) (rate(http_server_request_duration_seconds_count{graphql_operation_name!="IntrospectionQuery"}[$__rate_interval]))`, and for p95s by operation: `histogram_quantile(0.95, sum by(le, graphql_operation_name) (rate(http_server_request_duration_seconds_bucket{graphql_operation_name!="IntrospectionQuery"}[$__rate_interval])))`.

For coprocessors, we recommend also including details within this dashboard. Coprocessors are critical pieces of a router deployment, and as such, should be visible alongside core router metrics.

Consider raising some of the metrics here to the overview or related sections (e.g. resources) as well.

This would ideally be a measurement of CPU usage per router instance.

This chart should also include upper and lower bounds for memory utilization, helping visualize both under- and over-provisioning at a glance, especially at a pod level. 

This can help diagnose (for exmaple) Kubernetes resource limit issues, or instances acting abnormally.

This would ideally be a measurement of memory usage per router instance.

This chart should also include upper and lower bounds for memory utilization, helping visualize both under- and over-provisioning at a glance, especially at a pod level. 

This can help diagnose (for exmaple) Kubernetes resource limit issues, or instances acting abnormally.

Beyond general resource concerns (CPU, memory, potentially network throughput), it's also helpful to track datapoints specific to your infrastructure. 

In general, we recommend tracking metrics both as a whole (in effect an average of resource consumption), as well as per-instance consumption. 

As a result, it's often helpful to measure the number of instances being run as well, to help understand how much your supergraph may have scaled during operation.

Additionally, if using Kubernetes, usage against defined limits and pod/container restarts/backoffs can be helpful in troubleshooting.
